answer_html: \(P_{4} \equiv 15(1 - 11) \equiv 15(-10) \equiv -150 \equiv 6 \equiv G\mod{26}\) Thus, the plaintext was the word TRIG.
answer_latex: $P_{4} \equiv 15(1 - 11) \equiv 15(-10) \equiv -150 \equiv 6 \equiv G\mod{26}$ Thus, the plaintext was the word TRIG.

If needed, you can compute inverses modulo 26 via the Euclidean algorithm.

question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
First, we isolate for P in the given formula. To do this we need to compute the inverse of 7 modulo 26. We use the Euclidean algorithm to do this.

\[\begin{aligned} 26 &= 7(3) + 5\\ 7 &= 5(1) + 2\\ 5 &= 2(2) + 1\end{aligned}\]

and back substituting

\[\begin{aligned} 1 &= 5 - 2(2)\\ 1 &= 5 - (7-5(1))(2)\\ 1 &= 5(3) - 7(2)\\ 1 &= (26 - 7(3))(3) - 7(2)\\ 1 &= 26(3) - 7(11)\end{aligned}\]

and so the inverse of 7 modulo 26 is (-11) which is equal to 15 modulo 26. Hence

\(\displaystyle P = 15(7P) = 15(C - 11)\mod{26}\)

We plug in the four values of C given by \(\displaystyle OAPB = (14)(0)(15)(1)\) and see that

\[\begin{aligned} P_{1} &\equiv 15(14 - 11) \equiv 15(3) \equiv 45 \equiv 19 \equiv T\mod{26} \\ P_{2} &\equiv 15(0 - 11) \equiv 15(-11) \equiv -165 \equiv 17 \equiv R\mod{26} \\ P_{3} &\equiv 15(15 - 11) \equiv 15(4) \equiv 60 \equiv 8 \equiv I\mod{26} \\ P_{4} &\equiv 15(1 - 11) \equiv 15(-10) \equiv -150 \equiv 6 \equiv G\mod{26}\end{aligned}\]

Thus, the plaintext was the word TRIG.
sols_latex:
First, we isolate for \emph{P} in the given formula. To do this we need
to compute the inverse of 7 modulo 26. We use the Euclidean algorithm to
do this.

\begin{align*}
26 &= 7(3) + 5\\
7 &= 5(1) + 2\\
5 &= 2(2) + 1
\end{align*}

and back substituting

\begin{align*}
1 &= 5 - 2(2)\\
1 &= 5 - (7-5(1))(2)\\
1 &= 5(3) - 7(2)\\
1 &= (26 - 7(3))(3) - 7(2)\\
1 &= 26(3) - 7(11)
\end{align*}

and so the inverse of 7 modulo 26 is (-11) which is equal to 15 modulo
26. Hence

$\displaystyle P = 15(7P) = 15(C - 11)\mod{26}$

We plug in the four values of \emph{C} given by
$\displaystyle OAPB = (14)(0)(15)(1)$ and see that

\begin{align*}
P_{1} &\equiv 15(14 - 11) \equiv 15(3) \equiv 45 \equiv 19 \equiv T\mod{26} \\
P_{2} &\equiv 15(0 - 11) \equiv 15(-11) \equiv -165 \equiv 17 \equiv R\mod{26} \\
P_{3} &\equiv 15(15 - 11) \equiv 15(4) \equiv 60 \equiv 8 \equiv I\mod{26} \\
P_{4} &\equiv 15(1 - 11) \equiv 15(-10) \equiv -150 \equiv 6 \equiv G\mod{26}
\end{align*}

Thus, the plaintext was the word TRIG.
sols_raw:
First, we isolate for ''P'' in the given formula. To do this we need to compute the inverse of 7 modulo 26. We use the Euclidean algorithm to do this.

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
26 &= 7(3) + 5\\
7 &= 5(1) + 2\\
5 &= 2(2) + 1
\end{align}
</math>

and back substituting

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
1 &= 5 - 2(2)\\
1 &= 5 - (7-5(1))(2)\\
1 &= 5(3) - 7(2)\\
1 &= (26 - 7(3))(3) - 7(2)\\
1 &= 26(3) - 7(11)
\end{align}
</math>

and so the inverse of 7 modulo 26 is (-11) which is equal to 15 modulo 26. Hence

<math> \displaystyle P = 15(7P) = 15(C - 11)\mod{26}</math>

We plug in the four values of ''C'' given by <math> \displaystyle OAPB = (14)(0)(15)(1)</math> and see that

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
P_{1} &\equiv 15(14 - 11) \equiv 15(3) \equiv 45 \equiv 19 \equiv T\mod{26} \\
P_{2} &\equiv 15(0 - 11) \equiv 15(-11) \equiv -165 \equiv 17 \equiv R\mod{26} \\
P_{3} &\equiv 15(15 - 11) \equiv 15(4) \equiv 60 \equiv 8 \equiv I\mod{26} \\
P_{4} &\equiv 15(1 - 11) \equiv 15(-10) \equiv -150 \equiv 6 \equiv G\mod{26}
\end{align}
</math>

Thus, the plaintext was the word TRIG.
statement_html:
Decrypt OAPB, which was encrypted by the affine transformation

\(\displaystyle C \equiv 7P + 11 \mod{26}\)
statement_latex:
Decrypt OAPB, which was encrypted by the affine transformation

$\displaystyle C \equiv 7P + 11 \mod{26}$
statement_raw:
Decrypt OAPB, which was encrypted by the affine transformation 

<math> \displaystyle C \equiv 7P + 11 \mod{26}</math>
